abstract.original_text: Methods. We prospectively enrolled outpatients with influenza-like illness (ILI) presenting at 14 sentinel clinics located across the country from January through December 2009. The specimens were tested using real-time and multiplex reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction methods for the detection of 15 RNA respiratory viruses.

sentences.segment_text: We prospectively enrolled outpatients with influenza-like illness ( ILI ) presenting at 14 sentinel clinics located across the country from January through December 2009 .
The specimens were tested using real-time and multiplex reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction methods for the detection of 15 RNA respiratory viruses .

abstract.original_text: Results. We detected at least 1 respiratory virus in 365 of 561 specimens (65.1%). Overall, influenza virus was the most commonly detected virus (28.2% of specimens), followed by human rhinovirus (17.8%); parainfluenza virus (PIV) types 1-4 (7.5%); enterovirus (5.9%); respiratory syncytial virus (RSV; 5.7%); human coronavirus (HCoV) OC43, 229E, NL63, and HKU1 (5.3%); and human metapneumovirus (HMPV; 5.0%). RSV (26 of 31 specimens [83.9%]), PIV (30 of 39 [76.9%]), and HRV (64 of 99 [64.6%]) were most common among children <5 years of age. Coinfections were found in 53 of 365 positive specimens (14.5%), and most (71.7%) were in children <5 years of age. While influenza virus, enterovirus, RSV, and HMPV had a defined period of circulation, the other viruses were detected throughout the year.

sentences.segment_text: We detected at least 1 respiratory virus in 365 of 561 specimens ( 65.1 % ) .
Overall , influenza virus was the most commonly detected virus ( 28.2 % of specimens ) ,
followed by human rhinovirus ( 17.8 % ) ; parainfluenza virus ( PIV ) types 1-4 ( 7.5 % ) ; enterovirus ( 5.9 % ) ; respiratory syncytial virus ( RSV ; 5.7 % ) ; human coronavirus ( HCoV ) OC43 ,
229E , NL63 , and HKU1 ( 5.3 % ) ; and human metapneumovirus ( HMPV ; 5.0 % ) .
and HRV ( 64 of 99 ( 64.6 % ) ) were most common among children < 5 years of age .
Coinfections were found in 53 of 365 positive specimens ( 14.5 % ) ,
and most ( 71.7 % ) were in children < 5 years of age .
RSV , and HMPV had a defined period of circulation ,
the other viruses were detected throughout the year .

abstract.original_text: Conclusions. We found that respiratory viruses play an important role in the etiology of ILI in Cameroon, particularly in children <5 years of age.

sentences.segment_text: We found that respiratory viruses play an important role in the etiology of ILI in Cameroon ,
particularly in children < 5 years of age .
